message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the changing of seasons. Four times a year, we experience a change in climate as the seasons transition from winter to spring, spring to summer, summer to fall, and fall to winter. Option (B) is incorrect because there is no specific pattern for seeing a different person four times a year. Option (C) is incorrect because the moon goes through phases every month, not every season. Option (D) is incorrect because while we may see different stars in the night sky throughout the year, it is not specifically tied to a four times a year pattern.

This question requires basic knowledge about the changing seasons. Throughout the year, the climate changes as the Earth orbits the sun. We experience four distinct seasons - spring, summer, autumn, and winter - each with its own unique climate characteristics. Option (B) is incorrect because it is unlikely that a person would change four times a year. Option (C) is incorrect because the moon goes through phases, but these phases occur on a monthly cycle, not a quarterly cycle. Option (D) is incorrect because while we can see different stars throughout the year, the question specifies that the change occurs "four times a year," which is not related to star visibility.

Option (D) is incorrect because stars can be seen throughout the year, but they do not change in the same way that the climate does.
